newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Mideast violence surges, Clinton to meet Netanyahu.
newsitem.headline: Mideast violence surges, Clinton to meet Netanyahu.

text.p: Spiralling violence between Israelis and Palestinians has jeopardised peacemaking and prompted a pledge from President Bill Clinton to get involved personally.
Four Palestinians were killed on Tuesday in the bloodiest single day since peace moves hit a snag last month when Israel started building a new Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem.
Israeli officials said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would meet Clinton in Washington early next week for the first time since the violence erupted.
"We've got to try to keep the lid on things over there ... It is not going to be easy," Clinton said after meeting Jordan's King Hussein in the White House.

"I'm prepared personally to do anything I can to get this process back on track and move it forward, but I think the less I say about it the more likely I am to have some success in doing that," Clinton told reporters.
In the Palestinian-ruled Gaza Strip, two Palestinians were killed in explosions that Israel said were botched suicide bombings aimed at Jewish school children.
Hours later, Israeli forces shot dead two Palestinians in separate incidents in the West Bank as violence flared for a 13th straight day.
Hamas and the Islamic Jihad, groups whose militants have killed scores of Israelis in suicide bombings, said Israel was behind the blasts and vowed to take revenge.

"Qassam will not hesitate to respond to the Zionist crimes painfully and quickly in the heart of Tel Aviv and the biggest cities of the Zionist entity," said a leaflet issued by Izz el-Deen al-Qassam, Hamas's military wing.
The blasts occurred around 7 a.m. (0400 GMT) as settlers and school children were leaving the isolated enclaves of Kfar Darom and Netzarim south of Gaza City.

Palestinian security sources identified the two dead Palestinians as Anwar al-Shabrawi, 21, and Abdullah Ramadan al-Madhoun, 19, both from Jabalya. Israel Television said an anonymous caller claimed responsibility on behalf of the Islamic Jihad.
The violence mirrored a war of words between Israeli and Arab leaders that has erupted since Netanyahu broke ground for the settlement designed to tighten Israel's grip on Arab East Jerusalem.
Egypt, the first Arab state to make peace with Israel, said the settlement had brought roller-coaster Middle East peacemaking to a 20-year low point.

Netanyahu shot back, accusing Egypt of fomenting anti-Israel sentiment in the Arab world, which was considering a freeze on normalising ties and re-instating an economic boycott of the Jewish state. It was the harshest exchange in years.

Western officials said Washington was trying to put together a package of measures to defuse Israeli-Palestinian tensions. These would include accelerating talks on a final settlement of the 100-year-old Jewish-Arab conflict and an Israeli pledge to curb settlement.

The U.S. had hoped passions would cool on both sides after initial protests over the Jerusalem building project, but instead clashes have broken out in Palestinian towns and a Hamas suicide bomber killed three Israelis in a Tel Aviv cafe.

"The prime minister has decided to make a quick visit to the U.S. beginning this Sunday night. The prime minister...is happy to have an opportunity to meet President Clinton," said Netanyahu's office in a statement, adding that he would also meet administration officials and congressmen.
The U.S. has sponsored the talks since a 1991 Middle East peace conference in Madrid.
